comments.text:
Why are you all even bothering to exert the effort to say that this is not 
race based and not a crime? Did you fucking forget what the police are for? 
They're there to protect citizens and maintain peace in a civilized 
society, and yet this man, not a threat to anyone and being taken in for a 
PETTY crime, maybe a crime worth 40 fucking dollars, is totally worthy of 
being killed by the police after voicing that he can't breathe? They 
already have a bunch of guys pinning him down, why does the officer using 
the chokehold have to insist to keep using it even when he says to stop, 
which is a request that the camera guy can hear and he's not even in his 
face. And yes, that IS a chokehold. It's not a headlock, and a headlock 
will specifically not obstruct the airway of the person it's being used on. 
You can clearly see in the video his arm is wrapped around Eric's neck, it 
was not aimed to be anywhere else. Plus, the guy wraps his other arms 
underneath the guys armpit. If you do that to a friend, you can see that 
the hold underneath the arm is used in order to get a better grip and to 
also make it easier to press the neck tighter. You wanna say it's cause 
he's fat? What? Fat guys just start running and get out of breathe and then 
fucking die on the streets? Where do you live? The coroner said it was 
because of the force used on his throat. Fat guys don't just have some 
magical rope in their neck that tightens when cops grab them. Plus he said 
he couldn't breathe. Cops can hold him down while they call people to help 
him. They send killers to hospitals when they're wounded because they need 
them to stand trial, they send all kinda of criminals to the hospital 
because their job isn't to kill people. It's to detain. There was no reason 
for his death. Not once did Eric swing at them, just backed away. They 
could have easily detained him without his untimely death. They didn't even 
try to help him. No one was in danger. No one. This is an injustice and I'm 
sick of people trying to protect a cop who committed a murder right on 
camera. Police can be criminals, they can be corrupted. They are corrupted ﻿

comments.author: michaelterry1000

comments.text:
+michaelterry1000 His death was ruled a homicide by the coroner, with 
"compression of the neck and chest" as the primary contributing factors to 
his death, which was ruled Cardiac Arrest (a heart attack). Sure, you can 
blame his death on his poor health, and that such force on the side of the 
police would not have killed an average healthy male, but that takes away 
accountability from the officers in question.

There are several questions that need to be asked concerning these 
officers. Was the choke hold necessary? And if you don't classify it as a 
choke hold (like many do) what would be the explanation for the 
"compression of the neck" in the coroner's report? 


Was Eric Garner such a threat that four officers were required to hold him 
down? 


Was it necessary for an officer, when the hold was released, to place his 
hands on Garner's head and apply pressure?


Why did they not believe him when he gasped for air, saying he couldn't 
breath? And yes, you can speak when you're being choked. It's pure 
stupidity (And obviously dangerous) to assume that just because someone can 
speak, that their breathing isn't impaired enough to cause harm and/or 
death. 


Did Eric Garner's actions support the sudden escalation of force? Garner 
had a criminal record, and judging from his conversation in the video, one 
can assume that these cops stopped him on a weekly basis. Was Garner known 
to carry a weapon? Did he have combat training? 


In the video, Eric Garner is heard conversing with police, claiming that he 
hasn't done anything wrong, and that there are witnesses that support 
Garner's position. That he is consistently harassed (as he claims) by these 
same officers on a regular basis, and that he just wants to be left alone. 
When officers attempt to arrest him, he tries to pull away, and is almost 
immediately placed in a choke hold. He is quickly thrown to the ground, 
face down, where additional officers apply their weight and successfully 
handcuff him. Eric Garner was then rolled onto his side, and stayed in that 
position while the officers waited for an ambulance to arrive. 


My opinion is, that while the officer did not commit murder or 
manslaughter, (and thus, couldn't be indicted), they did in fact use 
excessive force. It was an unnecessary and rapid escalation that resulted 
in the death of a civilian. It indicates a failure in judgement on part of 
the officers, as they should be able to correctly identify and follow a 
proper course of action that minimize danger to the officer and the 
suspect, which they, in my humble opinion, did not do.

comments.text:
The greatest reason this President is playing the race card is because his 
actions have cost the Democratic Party many of the black voter.  Loss of 
confidence can be characterized by,

1)  Obamacare damaged many small businesses in the inner city.  Small 
businesses provided 70-80% of jobs for the inner city black community. 
 Huge numbers disappeared.
2)  Poor fiscal management by Democrats running the districts which contain 
many of the black communities.  Detroit, Philly, St. Louis, Oakland, LA, 
Flint, NJ, ...those cities are mostly broke, ...bond holders are not 
allowing them to keep issuing debt without securing more collateral from 
the municipalities.  Effectively killing government job expansion using 
debt instruments which the tax base can never support.
3)  Obama and Democrats promoted then signing the "sequestration" budget 
into effect, which will last until 2021.  The President and Congress will 
not be allowed to raise the spending without a super majority vote. 
4)  Obama ignoring the US immigration law then granting special immigration 
status without the consent of Congress.  His actions effectively allowed 5 
million to cross our Southern Boarder.  These 5 million competing for min. 
wage jobs created generational economic damage upon the black youth 
community.  Of the 500,000 black youths turning 18 yr each year, their will 
be no jobs for 10 years because of Obama engaging in Hispanic vote buying 
by ignoring US immigration laws and allowing 5 million to cross our 
boarders.

This latest mid-term election should be a clear warning of impending 
changes.  The Democratic Party lost 900 elected members, that's more than 
any previous President in history since the end of WW2.  The Democrats lost 
Fed. House, Fed. Senate, State Legislatures, Governors, Mayors, Municipal 
government elections totaling 900 in 6 years of Obama administration.  

The race card is the last bid of scorched earth policy in a desperate 
attempt to keep the PONZI scam, poor fiscal management, inability to fund 
or sustain pensions and entitlements.  Remember, NY Democratic Legislature 
had ordered the police to engage in forceful tax collection on tobacco 
stamps.  Garner was murdered for $6 tobacco tax stamp.  Garner was arrest 
nine time for not paying tobacco taxes of $6 or $54 in taxes.  If that is 
not a sign of desperate fiscal mess, ... a Liberal Progressive Democratic 
Government value $6 in taxes from tobacco stamps more than a human life!﻿

comments.text:
The problem is people who worry about everyone else and blame a whole race 
for all of society's ills. It's just plain old ordinary hate. Until you 
realize skin color has nothing to do with anything except hate, nothing 
will ever change. I am constantly reminded that I am responsible for 
slavery, segregation, and all racism placed on one race, because of my skin 
color. I was not alive back then, and assuming my "ancestors" are guilty is 
the biggest line of crock there is. Just because I'm  white, doesn't mean 
I'm automatically "guilty" of said crimes either. You can't tell by looking 
at me that I have Native American in me, nor can you tell that my very own 
ancestors were also slaves. Blaming the "whites" for society's problems is 
the same as blaming any other color, it's hate and assumption as well.
comments.author: exactimages

comments.text:

Black people can't be racist--they can only be prejudiced.  They lack the

comments.text:
Most Americans would welcome you with open arms.  I understand how the 
crazy can lead you to believe it's like that everywhere. The problem is 
when you have so many freedoms, you are going to get those who push the 
line, and there's almost no way to keep tabs on what everyone is doing. It 
does look like we are all crazy and violent, but there are millions and 
millions of us who are non violent, peaceable, non-biased, kind, and 
generous souls. We see people for who they are and most have good 
intentions. Crazy is just running the show and gets all the attention on 
mainstream media these days, so it does look quite scary at times. We have 
our problems and our tragedies, but we learn from them and lift one another 
up everyday. I would say, the government and the way it's been running 
lately, now that's scary. Blessings!
comments.author: exactimages

comments.text:
+Minkailu Lamin Yeah, American media always makes political stuff or the 
latest news look crazy. Just ignore the news and stuff along those lines, 
they tend to make people even here paranoid. But really, you'll probably be 
fine here. Especially when you see how much culture is here and how diverse 
it really is. Sure it's mostly white people, but America is a "melting 
pot." Depending on where you are, you might see africans Americans, asian 
Americans, mexican Americans, the list goes on and on. Lot's of different 
foods and sights to see and what not. It may look how you'd think at first, 
but once you're here for a while, you start to see the different things. 
(Did I mention, the FOOD IS AMAZING!!)

comments.text:
It's really not that bad in person. I live in the USA and it's actually 
very nice. I've never personally seen racism, but that depends where you 
live and on individuals you know. You'd be surprised, people can be quite 
nice. I get it though, every country can be stereotyped when watching media 
and you'd think, "Why would I ever go there?" But trust me, it isn't 
apocalyptic or anything. You'd be fine. Heck, you never know. You might 
love it. I lived here all my life, it's great (Can't speak for the rest of 
the nation, but where I am anyway)
